commentBody:
Having woken up in the middle of the night again, I opened the puzzle and proceeded with my first across and down pass. The result? Six answers, and I'm sort of sure about one of them ü§£

It's not looking like I will be able to make any progress with this one. I know almost none of the trivia entries, and the clues are nowhere near my wavelength. It's quite amazing how stumped I seem to be at the moment, actually. And it's not even Saturday!

Maybe I'll be back with an update later.
Very satisfying puzzle. SE gave me trouble but fell into place once I gave up on INSIDE DATA.

Wow what a tough one! Persistence paid off, no amount of googling helped (I try not to outright cheat with google but kind of indirectly look around for clues). A great brain bender, no ifs ands or buts!
Hardest Friday in a while. 25 minutes. Usually I can just keep cycling through the across and down clues until I'm done, but had to resort to zone defense on this one. A lot of good misdirects

My drama coach just made such a scene.

(He had acts to grind.)

Not knowing sportsball and not knowing Charles Mingus, HOtSTEP and bOT seemed plausible. Oops.

I let myself sometimes google things -- not clue answers per se, but facts or names or Things Found On Wikipedia -- so I looked up CM and went for the more-accurate P for the cross.

20A: Picture the baby, surrounded by the eager family. Baby speaks their first words:
 ‚ÄúMile‚Ä¶Stone‚Ä¶‚Äù

Baby may grow up to be a crossword constructor.

Wow, this was a very satisfying challenge and fought me every step of the way. Plus each corner was like a new puzzle. I couldn‚Äôt get PAYPERVIEW out of my head and that was my only ‚Äúeasy‚Äù answer on the NW, even though I thought I knew ANN but then rejected it. If I didn‚Äôt guess BUCS I don‚Äôt know how I would have gotten the SW; and then I thought it was UPAND‚Ä¶but I couldn‚Äôt parse ‚Äúsplit‚Äù as present tense. Finally SLOPPYKISS came to me magically with just the S somehow. In the SE SADKEANU was my only foothold which I hadn‚Äôt heard of but could guess. And in the NE I had FIRSTSTEPS until AJAR corrected me and gave me JOE. Nonetheless I can‚Äôt complain too much of the clueing except the acting president‚Äîto me there‚Äôs nothing about ‚Äúpresident‚Äù that connects to the clue, it could be acting anything. I was really looking to fit someone like George Schultz or Ed Meese or someone from the Reagan era which would have been brilliant. Just one of those puzzles you look at and say how the heck did I finish this!

This was definitely a challenge! But I enjoyed it. Personally, I got caught up in the BELIE, STOLID, HOPSTEP area. Tried "placid" for STOLID and "hotstep" for HOPSTEP (not a sports guy). I'm also not a jazz guy, so the Charles Mingus crossing clue wasn't much help!

A tough one, and only the thought of continuing my streak kept me going.  Even then, far too many lookups for comfort.

But hey, tomorrow is another day, as they say.
Steady straightforward satisfying solve. I must be getting better at this...

I started this in my usual spot, the NW, and got nothing, I then moved over to the NE and things started falling into place with DRAMA COACH, REGULAR JOE, and FIRST WORDS. The trend continued down to the SE corner, and then over to the SW. It was a bit slower coming back up, but eventually the NW fell into place.

This actually ended up being one of my faster Fridays, despite being tired.

Thanks, Adrian!

Like many others I found this one tough, well slower than my Friday average, but that made getting it cleanly all the more satisfying.  I don‚Äôt think there were any ‚Äòunfair‚Äô clues when crosses were used.

I apologize to everyone for this especially tricky Friday, designed entirely I‚Äôm sure to give me anxiety about hitting the streak benchmark of 2000!
Persistence paid off, but slower than my average (which is not a problem, just unusual).
I‚Äôve kept this streak going somehow through pandemic, cardiac arrest, and a variety of other crises; I wasn‚Äôt going to let some fanciful wordplay do me in!
sorry, wasn't a fan

The long answers were fantastic. I really wanted 16A to be JOESIXPACK.

I personally appreciated 46D as a BUCS lifer, but otherwise the short answers were kind of a pain to figure out. I think there‚Äôs more finesse to shuffleboard than SHOVING the disk. If you did that, it would slide way past the scoring zone.
This one certainly put up more resistance than many Fridays of late, but overall really enjoyed it. Some creative cluing led to a few satisfying aha moments.

This is not a complaint (kind of the opposite in fact), but it feels like the puzzles have been consistently more difficult on average in the past week or two than they have been for some time. Is it just me?

Very slow to get off the ground with this one - I think 10 minutes in I had about ten scattered answers which is usually unpromising. But in the end I finished it in a few minutes under an hour so I'm happy.

I don‚Äôt like to complain about someone else‚Äôs artistic achievement, so I‚Ä¶ won‚Äôt. But maybe there‚Äôs a reason Keanu is sad? 

(I just looked up this meme and he doesn‚Äôt look sad to me. He just appears to be watching the birds, and maybe trying to decide if he should share his sandwich.)
(I bet he shared.)

An Adrian Johnson byline is, for me, the equivalent of a warning label: "Danger. May cause hair-pulling." I'm not even sure how I finished the puzzle with only one check about halfway through. "Morose" instead of STOLID was holding me up in the East, and "Monosodium" instead of BONE MARROW had me spinning my wheels in the SW. Except for "monosodium" being a perfect fit, I had a feeling it couldn't be right because I'd never heard MSG being referred to by only its first two-thirds. Something else that threw me for a loop was Charles Mingus as BOP. I only ever knew him to be one of the greatest jazz musicians of all time. Going down a rabbit hole, it seems he played a great part in the *evolution* of bebop, being considered more as post-BOP. So TIL. In any case, I don't listen to jazz unless it's live and I can see it being played. But what I am into is whatever's [...very funky] and, much like Deb, not the REEKing kind. And so, here is Bill Withers with "Use Me," one of the best soul-funk grooves ever composed: https://youtu.be/NuYDKzky4z0?si=9M747uyNhhpPX54J Thank you, Adrian, for challenging me yet again. I hang on to the hope that someday I'll solve one of your grids with no hair-pulling nor a puzzle-check halfway through!

What a great Saturday puzzle.  Oops! a Friday, and now I'm worried about what the real one will be like.  This one was a challenge from start to finish, with so many clever fills to enjoy. (Anyone else still grinning about 4A?)  I had look-ups aplenty, but so what, they were worth it, and most of them were just confirmations anyway.  Stumbles like chowder and slurpy slowed me down, but OPAL cheered me up‚Äîa jewel in a jewel of a construction.

Adrian Johnson, your head must be bursting with clues you've dreamed and I'm looking forward to seeing them.  Thank you for the pleasure of solving this puzzle.

Like others, I found that much slower than average. My only quibbles are that I think 4A would've been much better clued as "Advisor to one acting as President", and that the crossing of both BOP and ELSTON with HOPSTEP requires an awfully precise set of arcane knowledge to get the answers without running the alphabet somewhere. 

(Not knowing either name, nor that a HOPSTEP is something a basketball player does, I had HOTSTEP/BOT for quite a while).
Loved the clue (and the answer) for 14A: ‚ÄúMouthful for the foulmouthed‚Äù üßºü´ß

I surly do hope that people at least aren't calling this the easiest puzzle they've ever seen.

Because at my normal solve time for a Friday, I still had a scandalous number of white spaces.  And by 1.5x my normal time I still had a nasty little SE corner that ended up having two or three bad entries, and it took till 2x normal to figure that out.

Even so, I had to scan for errors, and found a couple more, but still no joy.

Finally I ran the alphabet on the P in the cross of BOP and HOPSTEP, neither of which I'm particularly up on.

So I got by, but just barely.

Double my average time, but I can't complain about any of the answers.  I thought they were all legit; just hard!

I do think this would have been a worthy Saturday (and my time would have been slower than my Saturday average too).

Nice construction!

An utterly grueling puzzle. Woof! Left me drained. 

Well, the puzzle, plus my bawling six year old daughter (going on 13!) who was devastated when I told her the  luau shorts shorts she wore in Hawaii last year have gotten too short for her to wear to her Hawaiian themed last day of school tomorrow.

What a relief when I landed a clean solve! Don‚Äôt think my head would have made it through a fly speck. 

Mercifully, finished without a single typo to correct, Natick to ponder over, or alphabet to run.

Hopefully, tomorrow evening goes a bit smoother. On grid and off!

Yes! Y e s ! A Friday like Fridays used to be, and I‚Äôm positively giddy. Adrian, you made my day before I even started my coffee. What a treat to have a puzzle that threw up some resistance‚Äîand what fantastic, fresh and spunky fill. Jazz lover that I am, I know Charles Mingus very well, but with B _ _ in place, I filled in BOw, even though Mingus is known for his finger technique. (HOw STEP? Well, maybe‚Ä¶?) Because if you haven‚Äôt heard Charles Mingus‚Äôs visceral, poignant BOwing, you should. Here he is with Duke Ellington in Fleurette Africaine from the Money Jungle. Listen for that haunting sound of his arco. https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=uN8DPwUMa_U
Being sad, especially in these times, is nothing to be ashamed of.  Keanu is sad? So am I.

A challenging solve, to be sure.
My wheels fell off and I skidded all over this puzzle.

I did a few lookups and a few peeks to finish it.
Left me feeling like my soul had been sucked out.

The last few crosswords evoked so much
negative juju.  So much dark energy. 

Clues carry connotations, implications, and intentions. Entries
encodes values, beliefs, and culture. 
They may resonate with you or they may short you to ground.

Maybe I've connected too many dots.
Maybe my shields are down.
Maybe I need to adjust my word sensitivity controls.
Maybe I was reminded of Super Bowl LV.
  
If I ever build a puzzle‚Äîand realize
its filling with dark energy‚Äî
I'd smash it and begin anew.

Not my fastest Friday by a long shot, but fun nonetheless. The NE corner might have been the most challenging, where I tried FIRST stepS and the fortunately too-long I can hear you at 18A.

Of the many fun answers, I especially liked UP AND LEAVE and SLOPPY KISS. (It‚Äôs entirely possible that I hold the world‚Äôs record for the sloppiest kiss.)

Knowing about the SAD KEANU meme almost offset having no idea about Shanghai‚Äôs ART SCENE. 

Mr. Johnson, I can‚Äôt think of a puzzle of yours that I haven‚Äôt enjoyed. Keep up the great work!

Spent a very long time with REVELRY and SELENTP trying to find a way out. 

Eventually DEVILRY (a non word for me) surfaced and all was good. 

Needed Deb‚Äôs column to get the SILENTP exploit by then to be honest I didn‚Äôt care. 

Nice puzzle 

Thanks

Found a page of handwritten notes stuck behind the drawer of a bedside table rescued during a curb dive. Page is titled, "Possibilities"

Possibilities

Contacted agent to discuss concepts. Was ready to call it a day, but was told, Don't be silent, p, I'm all ears! Took notes, will revise later. So far:

1. Main character abandons lab, drifts down river (something about this bugs me. Might chew on it later, see if it gives birth to anything)

2. After prez skips party to watch his soap, a young regular Joe is a smash after hitting the right cord with diva. (Note: reader must keep door ajar for plot that will belie any LSD trip)

3. Expectant wife panics, decides to up and leave. Bucs convention, and has a lot to do in the kitchen. 

4. Not one more bad audition in our town,  heroine vows. She has inside dope on acting and her first words on stage impress drama coach. She sours on art scene, preferring sweeter fruit.

5. Hmm . . .a sloppy kiss at a party? Could lead to generations of trouble.
Can someone explain "doin" for neutralize?

I'm going to claim my five hundred words of reminiscing because I'm an old man.

And I like to think about things changing.

Elston Howard.  I instantly knew that because, and I'm ashamed to say this, but he was one of the very few black men on the Yankees (which I rooted for because they won all the time and I grew up in an area far away from any actual home team--I do expect several centuries of purgatory for that).

So he stood out.  And he was a great player.  I didn't get to see him often (or ever?) but he was a starter on the Yankees, and that was *way* more than good enough for me.

Respect.

I wasn't quite sentient when the color barrier was broken.  But the demographics of baseball have changed enormously *twice* over my lifetime.

Of course I do realize that had the USA actually lived up to its ideals, there wouldn't have been a need for the Negro Leagues (feels funny calling it that), and I would have known of a lot of other terrific black players in my early days.

Good puzzle. Tough but fair. Had to dig deep for VASCO Balboa, though it‚Äôs not a name I should‚Äôve forgotten since he was the first European to lay eyes on the ocean I see from my backyard. And he only did it half a millennium ago.

I just occurred to me that this forum would be the modern equivalent of the Algonquin Round Table, if the acoustics at the Algonquin were such that if you replied to someone who was replying to someone else, no one would ever hear you.

The Litter pickup area completely stumped me so thanks for the explanation in the comments. 

Did laugh out loud with cupboard component. That was very clever. 

Tough puzzle but hey it is Friday

Of course, many nice points on a puzzle composed by one who has written so many for the NYT.

But it seems there is not so much editorial supervision as there should be‚Äî some of these clues/answers aren‚Äôt just reaching, they‚Äôre wrong. Devilry is not mischief, opals are not milky and etc etc.

A perfect Friday grid. 

Elston Howard and Charles Mingus.  'I've got ears', 'silent p', Shanghai, pho, there's a lot going on ! 

Nice one.

Whew (again). Relieved to see that for once I'm not the only who really struggled with this. Had to look up some things and... cheat just a bit, but managed to get through it. Seven debut answers and six more that only appeared once previously. That's... pretty fresh. 

Puzzle find today is one of the most unusual I've ever encountered. I'll put that in a reply. 

...

From the comments I see mixed responses to today‚Äôs puzzle- I am firmly in the ‚Äúloved it‚Äù column. Lots to help solve the clues I didn‚Äôt know by themselves, slow burn in some corners - but enough crossover to get there.  I‚Äôd take these puzzles any day over contrived themes and rebus‚Äô.  I guess I am just a simple soul at heart.  Thanks for a satisfying solve!

After my first pass, I had only a handful of answers filled in, and I wasn't entirely sure of quite a few.  I actually looked at the top of my puzzle to make sure it was a NYT puzzle and that it was, in fact, Friday.  

And I did that twice. 

This came together like a puzzle from the archives.  Slow, fill in, erase, sometimes put back in, etc. until it miraculously came together.  A perfect Friday.

Clever. NAPE, SILENT P, SOAP, DO IN, LAB
Got practically nothing at first but chipped away, or 'cycled' as someone has put it, and slowly solved it with some single square reveals, and all of ARTSCENE.

For non-American English speakers, it's still  a double challenge - first simply knowing the word eg BELIE and then using language knowledge/general knowledge to hazard a guess eg CLAMDIP for words one's never heard of. TUDE is a bit weird to me!

I'd forgotten about SCADS, though I'm remembering 'a tad'.

ATTA flour is in all the supermarkets, because of lots of people of Indian heritage where I live. 

Trivia for me I would say HESS, ASADA, SAD KEANU, BUCS.

But FUNKY means it REEKS/smells? When did that happen? I thought FUNKY referred to music!
It was nice to have a fair amount commenters who found this quite tough, so often not the case.  I liked the variety of entries, and didn‚Äôt mind getting help with some unknowns.

I usually expect Friday clues to be at the very least somewhat obtuse - but some of these were just outright poor. "You can count on me" translating to YES when there are so many other ways you can clue the monosyllable in feels unnecessary. Same for a good few other clues that just could've been far better hinted at: CALL IT A DAY, VERBALLY, UP AND LEAVE, etc. OREO PIEs are not a thing despite NYT consistently forcing in Oreo-related clues as if it was the only flavour for anything.

I will say though, DRAMA COACH and SILENT P made me chuckle.

Anyone else confidently slap in TEE for [Culture center?]?





Et tu, emu.

This is a puzzle with my favourite kind of theme, and the theme is a feeling - of cautiously finding my way through a darkened maze in which the master architect has placed just enough dusty light switches to allow you to find your way, and appreciate and learn about the interesting, hidden artwork.

(This positive buzz of course means I didn‚Äôt find it quite as hard or obscure as some of the 25+ year-old ones in the archive. But still lots of brow-furrowing.)

Great Friday!
"Perfect" as verb vs noun are not homophones, they are homographs / heteronyms. Homophone means "same sound", that is, same pronunciation. Wikipedia has a nice Venn diagram with all these terms.

I had nada after my first pass through the acrosses.  Well that‚Äôs not true, I did have TADA. Never mind, I thought.  The downs are usually easier. And they were. Marginally. I chipped away very slowly, but the NW proved very stubborn and I despaired of completing the puzzle without a lookup or two.  I‚Äôm going to blame my sluggish thinking on the fact that I was solving while half watching the exciting first game of the NBA finals on national tv.  Whatever the case, I finally gave up and went to bed, the first time I failed to complete the puzzle in one sitting in awhile. In the morning, an answer that should have been obvious to me, NATIONALTV for big game medium, suddenly became glaringly obvious, and the rest of the puzzle fell into place. Doh!  

At that point I went from frustrated by this puzzle to enchanted.  The SW  with BONEMARROW, UPANDLEAVE, CANTILEVER, and SLOPPYKISS all being crossed by SILENTP was some real DEVILRY.
Really like this puzzle‚Äôs unusual grid that made it unusually  challenging.

This was a funny solve for me.

I‚Äôm a stickler for solving with a pattern
(mornin‚Äô, OCD), and today I completed 
sections before moving on, but in a 
wobbly-bobbly way.

But loved the solve. 
A solid Friday.
üëç

In early week puzzles, the leap from clue to answer is often instantaneous.  Later in the week, you get The Gap, where the answers don‚Äôt slap down, where the art is in creating clues that don‚Äôt give the answer away but are close enough to where a cross or a riddle-crack will make them click.

Adrian is so good at making these type clues, clues that make a puzzle opaque at first, then openings start happening.  

He is also so good at designing and filling a grid.  Today we have a Times debut design that allows for 16 bigs, and man, does he take advantage of them ‚Äì BONE MARROW, FIRST WORDS, I‚ÄôVE GOT EARS, NOT ONE MORE, REGULAR JOE, SLOPPY KISS (all these are Times answer debuts!), not to mention UP AND LEAVE, and CALL IT A DAY.

And may I bring your attention to the four-stacks in the NE and SW.  You almost always see junk in four-stack crosses ‚Äì it is expected, actually.  But today, not a tinge of ugliness.  Actually, look at all the answers in this super-low 66-word grid ‚Äì ugliness be gone.  Wow! 

Beauty in the box today, showcasing the art and science of puzzle-making, and creating, for me at least, a most splendid outing.  Thank you so much for this, Adrian!

I enjoyed the Mingus clue, although it unaccountably took  to me longer to come up with BOP than it should have, because my mind was stubbornly fixated on the instrument on which he was a virtuoso, the bass, even though that clearly didn‚Äôt fit.  Mingus was a towering figure, both figuratively and literally in the history of jazz, and though he could be hard on his bandmates because he was a perfectionist, he fostered the careers of many fine jazz musicians, including Eric Dolphy and Mal Waldron.  

Iconoclastic until the end, in his last months he embarked on one of the oddest musical collaborations ever, as he worked with another iconic North American musician, the great singer/songwriter, Joni Mitchell.  Other jazz musicians had scorned her earlier attempts to infuse her music with jazz elements, but Mingus, recognizing a sympathetic talent, by all accounts, took her under his wing.  The resulting album he inspired, Mingus, while not one of Joni‚Äôs most beloved efforts, is complex and fascinating music.  It is worth a listen just for Joni‚Äôs version of what is perhaps Mingus‚Äôs signature tune, Goodbye Pork Pie Hat, a tribute to saxaphonist Lester Young, to which Joni authored some respectful lyrics.

Anyone interested in exploring the work of Charles Mingus would do well to start with perhaps his most accessible record, simply titled Ah Um.
Shout out to all those who complete the puzzle without autocheck turned on. If I had tried that today, I think I would‚Äôve thrown my iPad at the wall.

Yikes! The OED lists three *individual* entries for "funky"(adj.), and ten(!) for "funk" (n. or v.)--it's hard to say which came from which, but it looks like the original had to do with smoking cheap, smelly tobacco. I'd guess that at the height of their careers, Solage (1389)* or Tone Loc (1989)** could afford a better grade. *ttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=v1RDIQ-nOXs) **https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rzw5TWtEE-E

He who PANICS loses his streak.

But came pretty [foulmouthed] close today!

Nice Friday puzzle.  Lots of original entries and a minimum of trite crossword-ese fill.  (Even OREO had the dignity to be part of a PIE.)

Favorite clue: "Mouthful for the foulmouthed".
Smallest nit:  When was the last time a parent threatened a child with a mouthful of SOAP?

By using two Super Bowl years in the clue, the decision to go with BUCS is forced on you.  But there is a wrinkle, since most fans think of the victory year as the one during which the regular season was played - i.e. the prior year. After all, that is what is displayed on the Gillette Stadium Ring of Honor - commemorating  championships  in 2001, 03 and 04 among others while being careful to list the Roman numerals of each Super Bowl in question. So there is a very good chance that a New Englander, or for that matter any fan that has recall of the list of NFL winners would automatically say that the PATS (also 4 letters) won in 2093.
A struggle, but ultimately doable!
Tough little puzzle but very enjoyable.
TIL there was no Elster Howard. Just the one lookup, I‚Äôm keeping my streak.

Of all the entries today, the one that bugged me was CLAM DIP: I mean, why would you bring a seafood appetizer to a seafood cookout? Isn't clam dip the thing you'd take--along with the chapati and the oreo pie--to *tomorrow's* social gathering, made with the leftovers from *yesterday's* clam bake? I haven't been to a clam bake in years, not since the annual ones my godparents would host, often in our back yard (we had a swimming pool), but I remember being served MUGSful of steamy clam broth. At the time I found it disgusting; now, what I wouldn't give to taste it again! Speaking of clam bakes, heard about the one Hern√°n and His Boys had in Darien, right after he pushed Vasco off the cliff?: https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poems/44481/on-first-looking-into-chapmans-homer
I recommend the Wikipedia article on Cephalopod . Using it to check my choice of SAC was very educational. Great puzzle!

For 32 down, I was convinced that "How many consent?" Involved a tALLY. That gave me VERtALLY. 

Which left me thinking about "vertus," the Latin root for "verify" and other words...

Yeah, I overthought it just a bit.

Looked it up, stole the gold star, and moved on.
Elston Howard has had me surfing Baseball Reference where I rediscovered that Roger Maris won the American League MVP Award two years in a row. Quite an accomplishment on that team.
This Friday puzzle was as tough as a Saturday for me.

Now that was *not* a "themeless Wednesday" puzzle! Quite a workout for me. No errors or assistance, but took me almost 40 minutes.

What DEVILRY in this grid: DOIN, SADKEANU (new to me), LAB (not TEE for "Culture center?"), NATIONALTV, SILENTP, TUDE.

OPAL took me a bit---and why isn't Outback capitalized? "Litter pickup area?" for NAPE is cute, but the singular NAPE doesn't seem right to me. I mean, a litter doesn't have a NAPE. But, whatever. I've never played shuffleboard---is SHOVES rather than SLIDES a standard usage?

Amazing fill in the grid. Another competitor for a puzzle of the year. I hope we get a lot more Friday and Saturday puzzles like this one.
Southwest corner was pure Friday...had some real nice 'tude. Well played Adrian...TGIA!
I adored this puzzle. Almost every answer gave me a chuckle once I figured it out. And yes I used Autocheck but I didn't look anything up on Google - I promise!
Anyone else absolutely positively sure it was OBAMA  COACH?

Constructor Brutality!  
Speaking of DEVILRY...(that's a word? I wd have thought DEVILTRY--see the T?)

I take it VASCO was a popular boys' name in the late 1400's....

The SE stack really had me in a headlock...  I had HOPsomething, BELIE, and STOLID --and I began to doubt all of them!  The elusive TADA seemed impossible.  I *almost* wished we had watched the seemingly ubiquitous "John Wick"  programs.

My big breakthrough came when (in tones of astonished "who would know this?!" pain) I read the 39D clue to DHubby...I mean, 1963??  I was a HS sophomore in a non-sports-fan family!  But DHubs instantly blurted out ELSTON (I had ELMORE on the tip of my pen)....

Is SCAD in the singular actually a word? Meaning, "a word that people would ever use"?  (I suspect that SCADs of huffy solvers are racing to Reply with the fruits of their research.)
See you tomorrow unless I melt...HOT and HUMID!

Today's puzzle is rated Very Hard, with a median solve time of 20:24 and the median solver 48% slower than average.  I am happy to say I beat that, but not my own Friday average.

For me, this puzzle hearkened back to the days when I more consistently had to go slowly, wound up with more white space than filled-in space after the first pass, wound up with more white space than filled-in space after the second pass, and the dreaded feeling that maybe I might not finish this one.  (Although these days, I have the confidence that although it will take longer, I will eventually get everything.)

Of course, a lot of people say that in the past, puzzles were consistently harder, but I also think I'm a better solver than I was, say, 10 years ago.

The reason for this extra difficulty seemed to be vagueness of clues.  For example, I saw [New ___] and thought it was most likely AGER, but it didn't have to be.  After all, the puzzle comes out of another "New (four letters)."  So many clues seemed like they could have been various things, or nothing came to mind at all.

My strategy, then and now, is to put in any factually based gimmes (ANN, SAC) and strong guesses (OPAL, ODOR), and try to get a foothold somewhere.  This time, it was the SE, and from there, I managed to circle around the puzzle until all was done.

Feel the need to add to the posts from the folks who liked this one to help balance out the board a bit.
Personally, I was pleasantly surprised to be challenged again on a Friday. I found the last handful of Friday puzzles to be fun enough but lacking the level of difficulty Friday's deserve.
Finished it clean about 7 minutes above my average. I thought that was perfect.
The clueing was misleading and creative; I have no idea where people are getting "dark" from, but to each their own.
Anyway, thanks for the tough but fun Friday, Adrian. For me, it was a great start to the day.

Good puzzle. I got stuck for a bit in the SW by entering ‚Äúplacid‚Äù for 41A and then ‚Äúpushes‚Äù for 41D.

Also regretted having to rip out ‚ÄúJoe Sixpack‚Äù for 16A.
I don‚Äôt understand why themeless puzzles have more white space. Can anyone here enlighten me?

As a person of low self esteem, I am delighted to read many of you found this puzzle difficult.  The, ‚Äúit look you longer to solve todays puzzle that your average Friday‚Äù message made me sad. 

Just yesterday. I was telling someone I consider myself a Friday level solver.  Then this puzzle. Then imposter syndrome.  Haha

This may sound absurd, but I'm being serious.

For two days I've been mostly unable to access Wordplay and the comments. I say 'mostly' because I could get to and see the Wordplay column, but only for a few seconds. Then the page would go completely blank. Poof.

Restarting my computer didn't help.

Today it's working again. Well, what passes for working these days. 

Has this happened to anyone else?

I'd contact customer service, but why. They tell us they care, but they don't show us.

‚ÄúHow and why did rebus puzzles get started?‚Äù ‚Äî Toni, Cincinnati

From Christina Iverson:

I was surprised to learn from my research that the first rebus puzzle was published much earlier than I would have expected. For those unfamiliar with the concept, a rebus puzzle (sometimes called a rebus element) is any puzzle where a square contains anything other than a single letter. This could be a number, a symbol or multiple letters. It might even be a combination of two letters ‚Äî one each for the Across and Down entries.

Roberta Morse made the first rebus puzzle that was published in The New York Times in 1954. It had the numbers 1 to 4 in different quadrants of the grid; there was a numeral 1 in the first square, with the answer 1-DOWN clued as [First vertical word] at 1-Down. A few months later, Roberta‚Äôs husband, Anthony Morse, made the second rebus puzzle we published. This one had the four card suits placed in different quadrants of the puzzle. Since the puzzle was published in print, the assumption was that solvers would draw in a little diamond rather than write out the word ‚Äúdiamond.‚Äù This puzzle had entries like ‚ù§Ô∏èACHE and ‚ô¶Ô∏èMINES.

@Treegarden

Themes commit a constructor to more short words because the theme answers are usually three or four rows apart.  More short words mean more blocks (black squares).

Also, themeless puzzles have sections of longer entries (stacks) that don't require as many blocks.

Maximum numbers of blocks are set by the editorial staff so as to reduce the choppiness of themeless puzzles.  The maximum is a bit higher for themed puzzles because themes cannot be carried out with as strict a constraint.  And, as with yesterday's puzzle, a themer with short theme words (due to the trick), any rule can be suspended in service of the theme (hence even more blocks).

Hope this helps!

Other early rebus puzzles included one with a single dollar sign, one with five ampersands and one with apostrophes. Of the first 10 rebus puzzles, five used numbers. From 1954 to 1974 The Times ran 16 rebus puzzles, averaging less than one a year. These days, we‚Äôre running them far more frequently ‚Äî in 2024 alone, we ran 26 rebus puzzles.

As for why rebus puzzles got started, crossword constructors are always trying to find ways to do new things in puzzles. Once someone decided to put numbers in the grid, it opened up the door ‚Äî what else can you put in a square? Once a rule is broken, it can often inspire other constructors to challenge that rule in different ways. What rules would you like to see broken in crosswords?
